item.title: The Zero TB Initiative - talk by Mercedes Becerra
item.description: Notes from a talk from the Global Health Delivery Partnership Grand Rounds series. Title: Principles of Tuberculosis Elimination and the Zero TB Initiative Presenter: Mercedes Becerra, ScD. Professor, Department of Global Health and Social Medicine, Harvard Medical School Associate Epidemiologist, Division of Global Health Equity, Brigham and Women’s Hospital Senior TB Specialist, Partners In Health A substandard of TB control has been mainstream Based on current trend, it will take 200 years for the global incidence to be at the same level as TB incidence in the US.

item.title: Timely vaccines
item.description: Notes from a talk by Kendall Hoyt, ID epi seminar series. During WWII, the world is very productive in developing and improving many vaccines. Many barriers are organizational, not scientific. What are some of the good organizational characteristics that facilitate speedy development? Top down governance Integrated across developmental phases and diciplines Situated in a community that facilitates information transfer CEPI (Coalition for Epidemic Preparedness Innovations) - defines the problem as a speed problem.

item.title: About
item.description: I am a graduate student in epidemiology in the Harvard T.H. Chan School of Public Health. I’m interested in using epidemiologic methods to identify targeted interventions for high risk populations. Before starting my doctoral degree, I worked in the London School of Hygiene & Tropical Medicine studying cancer survival disparities in the UK, France and Japan. For my doctoral thesis, I am working on using both infectious disease modeling and machine learning techniques to inform tuberculosis control strategies.

item.title: Research
